title: Can dust and debris working its way inside of my wireless mouse cause it to become ineffective and non-functional or hard to get it to work when I try to click on something, and has anyone else ever had this same problem? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: Can dust and debris working its way inside of my wireless mouse cause it to become ineffective and non-functional or hard to get it to work when I try to click on something, and has anyone else ever had this same problem? Apart from a build up of debris that may affect the optical sensor, which I have not experienced personally, the only issues I have had were intermittent operation of the mouse buttons, particularly the left click button and the scroll wheel became intermittent in its operation. I was able to clean the scroll wheel, but the microswitches for the buttons were sealed and it would have been a case of replacement rather than cleaning, so I replaced the whole mouse with a different make.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Gus Henry Bates

response.answer_text: As far as movement is concerned, only to extent that it blocks the light path from source to surface and back to the sensor. However, you can see that area and it should be easy to clean out. As far as the switches are concerned, it is certainly possible. It is even fairly common for a scroll wheel. Not so common for the other switches. (They are usually pretty well sealed.)
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Gus Henry Bates

response.answer_text: Yes it’s possible that you could wear out the switches & also on the click mechanisms. Also the optical port can become plugged with Dust & dirt, causing the malfunction of the cursor itself.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Gus Henry Bates

response.answer_text: Nope . UNLESS - unless it a trackball mouse .
